title: 107_hr3223
content:
The Act is titled the "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" aims to ensure safe water supply and wastewater systems for residents of the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. It authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to plan, design, and construct these systems in collaboration with the Jicarilla Apache Nation, including service connections to facilities in Dulce and the surrounding area. Additionally, the Act requires the Secretary to enter into a self-determination contract with the Jicarilla Apache Nation upon request. The Jicarilla Apache Nation will plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems with oversight from the Bureau of Reclamation. The Nation will assume ownership and responsibility for the system. The Jicarilla Apache Nation will plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems with oversight from the Bureau of Reclamation. The Nation will assume ownership and responsibility for the system. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Act", "BIA", "Irrigation", "Reclamation", "Report", and "Reservation" related to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act. The Act defines key terms related to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act, including Reservation, Rural Water Supply Project, State, Secretary, and Tribe. The Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System is addressed in Section 4 of the Act. The Rural Water Supply Project, in collaboration with the Tribe, aims to improve water supply and wastewater facilities in Dulce, New Mexico, and surrounding areas. It includes facilities for water supply, pumping, treatment, distribution, and collection on the Reservation. The Rural Water Supply Project aims to improve water and wastewater systems on the Reservation, including construction, replacement, and repair of existing systems. This includes appurtenant buildings, access roads, property rights, and other necessary facilities to meet water supply needs. The tribal share of the project cost includes designing and initiating construction of the wastewater treatment plant and other essential infrastructure. The tribal share of the Rural Water Supply Project includes costs for designing and initiating construction of various water infrastructure. The Federal share covers the remaining project costs identified in the Report. Upon completion, the Tribe will assume responsibility for operation, maintenance, and replacement of the project. Upon completion of the Rural Water Supply Project, the Tribe will be responsible for the operation, maintenance, and replacement costs as outlined in the Act and the Operation, Maintenance, and Replacement Plan. The Secretary has the authority to enter contracts and promulgate regulations to implement the Act and the Indian Self-Determination Act. Project requirements are outlined in Section 6. The Secretary will prepare a project plan for the Rural Water Supply Project within 60 days of funds availability. The Tribe will develop an OM&R plan for operations and maintenance. A construction manager will be selected to work with the Tribe. A memorandum of agreement will be made for the transition plan during construction. The Secretary will enter into a memorandum of agreement with the Tribe for a transition plan regarding operations and maintenance of the Rural Water Supply Project. Oversight responsibility will be with the Secretary, who will also provide technical assistance to the Tribe. The service area of the project will be within the Reservation boundaries, and the project will be subject to the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Rural Water Supply Project will be subject to the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Secretary will report to Congress on the project's progress annually. Title to the project will be held in trust for the Tribe by the United States. Authorization of appropriations for the Rural Water Supply Project is set at $45,000,000. Funds cannot be used for construction until appraisal investigations, feasibility studies, and environmental requirements are met. Prohibition on using funds for irrigation purposes is also specified. SEC. 9. WATER RIGHTS.

The water rights of the Jicarilla Apache Tribe are included in the Water Rights Settlement Act and adjudicated under New Mexico State law. These rights provide sufficient water for the municipal water system without impacting other tribal water rights or endangered species.
